hey you guys have monitors that you like?
what kind of monitor do you want is a better starting point
like do you want ultrawide 21:9 or standard 16:9 or maybe 16:10

Ok so I am trying to wrap a class inside of a thread
<https://github.com/nishtahir/LiquidThings/blob/master/app/src/main/java/com/nishtahir/androidthings/liquidcrystal/io/LiquidCrystal.java>

text: I basically want to wrap this so that whatever interaction the mainactivity has with it, is posted to a separate thread
How about creating a class that have an executor that will manage LiquidCrystal?
LiquidCrystalExecutor
Explain
Let me ask first do you need multiple threads?
Nah
Just one background thread for it
And one last question, does your Liquid crystal need to be runnable?
Nah… I wanted to post it initially
but then I decided to think about it a bit more
Hmmm then I guess you can create a class like this
<@U0ESBF4AV> Got something?

file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
public class LiquidCrystalExecutor {
	private ExecutorService executorService = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor();
	private LiquidCrystal liquidCrystal;
	
	public LiquidCrystalExecutor(LiquidCrystal liquidCrystal) {

text: <@U08GFT5V5> Sorry was thinking
Yeah I understand, It is a difficult problem
But then after seeing it again, instead of using ExecutorService you can also use the newer and more beautiful RxJava :smile:
Yeah I chose not to in order to keep the complexity down
I see
but turns out it’s a nice learning experience
Then use ExecutorService and avoid using threads directly
you can also create a set of callable
and add your task into the callable, and then invoke them use ExecutorService.invokeAll()
and get list of Future from that call
Well the goal here is to avoid doing any GPIO stuff on the main theread

<@U08GFT5V5> I would likely use a mediator pattern or a bus

as <@U0ESBF4AV> describes, an executor would be an implementation specific answer but I dont know that I would want to throw an executor into already working code just to solve a problem so a mediator is likely the best answer
Well how would it work

<@U3SPUAL48|lastman> has joined the channel

make an interface that has all the public methods, make that class implement it (aka don’t change it)

make an implementation of the interface that appropriately passes work to a single thread executor as <@U0ESBF4AV> described. Since it seems it’s write only in that class, you seem golden.
the mediator could be made to ‘take’ an executor as I imagine you don’t want multiple threads writing to gpio
so work would get queued up naturally in the order requested
I guess the only issue with all of that is the constructor of that class
Nice one <@U055GGAHS> ! :+1:
Yeah the constructor is a pain
you likely need a factory that also uses the executor to generate the class for you on the proper thread, you can use handler thread as a way to do that
then you dont need the executor at all tbh
Ok so this is starting to go over my head
Threading is a weakness I have
Could someone put together an example of how this would work?
I’m a little confused :confounded:
yeah give me a couple minutes
<@U08GFT5V5> <https://github.com/ToxicBakery/ThreadedObjectMediator>

attachments.title: ToxicBakery/ThreadedObjectMediator
attachments.text: ThreadedObjectMediator - Example project for performing work on an object implementation via a mediator that performs threading on the target implementation.

text: something like that
the constructor of the WriteStuffMediator is a bit strange given that you have the requirement of needing to construct the target object inside the mediator thread
if at all possible I would move those comms out of the constructor and into a required call
that simplifies everything and as written it ‘should’ be trivial to write testing for all the classes I created
the WriteStuffNoOp is optional and more of a defensive implementation than a requirement prevent the possibility of the atomic reference ever being null

I should also comment that the atomic reference shouldn’t be necessary at all given that only the handler thread gets/sets the ref but since the setter method doesn’t enforce a thread, I felt it was again better to be defensive about it
so why isn't <@U08GFT5V5> using RxJava again?
so without getting too much into a rant.. generally fuck rxjava
:open_mouth:
Rx is life
nah rx makes debugging hell
nuh-uh
use a time-traveler
lol
the thing about rx isn’t that rx itself is bad
I think using it with java ends up with unexpected results that can be extremely difficult to understand
Such complexity for what is a conceptually simple task
not that manual threading saves you from that but the issues are typically much more obvious in nature
I need to study this a bit
<@U055GGAHS> :taco: :nutella:
yeah let me know if you have questions
